dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheap short-stay motel room. A strip of daylight shows between drawn curtains at one of the windows. A woman is sitting on the edge of the bed, her back to us. She's on the phone. We track slowly toward her as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (into phone) There was a time when I trusted my husband, but I can't anymore. (listens) I think he's seeing another woman. (listens) Well, I'm told that you're very good at what you do. (listens) That's fine. What time? (listens) Okay. I'll be there. We are in a close shot now. The woman hangs up the phone and turns around, and we see her face. She's beautiful. She's in her early thirties, very well-put together. Her name is GLORIA CONOVAN.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: How was I? Sitting in a chair, across the room, in the corner, is a man. His suit jacket is draped over the arm of the chair and his tie is loosely knotted. He has a wary look. He's about thirty-five. His name is JOHN MACDONALD.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: .-.Good. He lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Can I have one of those? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you quit.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (smiling) I guess I'm just not good at giving things up. She rises from the bed and crosses the room. He shakes a cigarette loose from the pack. She takes it, holds it up to her lips. He lights it for her. She smokes in slow, steady pulls.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really am trying to quit.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (smiling) It doesn't count if someone else lights it. She goes to the bureau, primps in the mirror, surveys herself critically, is reasonably satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm just thinking. Someone you know could drive by and see your car.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No one I know ever comes up here. Why -- you afraid we'll get caught?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Maybe. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Aren't you? She makes a careless gesture with her cigarette, flicks the ashes into an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should be.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (playfully) You think someone's following you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's cute.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (teasing) Your ex-wife, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Another woman?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (unsmiling) There are no other women. Only you. Besides, I don't think you're in a position to be jealous.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (archly) Who says I'm jealous?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I do. She gives him a sly smile. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're putting words in my mouth. He's a little annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So you wouldn't mind if I was seeing other women?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (still playing) Are you gonna cross-examine me, counselor?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. I might.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You "might" -- what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Is that a rhetorical question?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No. She blows a slanting plume of smoke. It swirls around her head.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It means you're having an affair with a married woman.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Does it ever bother you?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That you're married. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Does it bother you? He takes a deep drag on his cigarette and then crushes it out in the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I should get back to the office. She stubs out her cigarette and sits down on the bed. She gives him a languishing, inviting look.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You don't really want to go out into that heat, do you? He stares at her, absorbing the lines of her figure, the slim legs sheathed in silk stockings.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's not much cooler in here. She slides her skirt up her thighs, revealing the creamy flesh between her stocking tops.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What'1l I do with myself? He drifts toward her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You could go home to your husband.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I will. Just not yet. She reaches for him, pulling him down onto the bed. They tug at each other's clothes, kissing deeply.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Why do I keep taking these chances? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...you can't help yourself. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A concrete grandstand with a tacky, art-deco look. Gloria's Mercedes convertible turns into the parking lot. Gloria parks, gets out, looks around. She has dark sunglasses on.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Conovan? She turns. At the end of a row of cars, a stout, florid man in his early fifties is standing next to a well-battered Crown Victoria. He's dressed in a rumpled summer weight suit and a wide-brimmed Panama hat. He has the face of a man who's seen things. This is NED BEAUMONT. Gloria approaches him. He smiles. There's something oily and smooth about him. He extends a fat pink hand. She shakes it. He walks around the car and opens the passenger side door. She gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mess. Paper napkins on the floor, a bottle of No Doz, a few soda cans, a couple of those little cartons take-out burgers come in. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Beaumont settles himself into the driver's seat and look over at Gloria. She twists her lips, showing her distaste.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (noting her expression) I work out of my car.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I never would've guessed.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Thought this would be more private.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You meet all your clients here?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Well, I spend a lot of time here. I like watching the dogs run. (a beat) I take it you've never been to the races.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: It's a funny thing. The dogs chase this mechanical rabbit around the track, but they can never catch it. They just keep chasing it around in circles. You'd think maybe with a little luck one of ‘em might catch up to it, but it always gets away. She turns and gazes out the window.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I've never been a great believer in luck. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Let's talk about what you believe in.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I believe my husband's having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Well, what you believe and what you can prove are two different things. What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (evenly) A wife can tell.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: How long've you been married?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ten years.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Has he been unfaithful before?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: ...Yes. He fixes his small, shrewd eyes on her.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: But you didn't have him followed.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Why now?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I never had a reason to leave. (a beat) Now I do.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ...-John recommended me? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I didn't think there were private detectives anymore, except on TV.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Well, it's not what you think. A lot of the time I just sit in my car and stare at motels. Last night I was parked outside a motel for five hours, waiting for a lady's husband to come out with his girlfriend. My eyes're still bleary with neon. Got some good pictures, though. In the closeness of the car, he is starting to sweat. He digs into his pocket, takes out a sodden handkerchief, blots his forehead with it.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know if you come to the track at night, they don't let you take pictures. They say it spooks the dogs. I don't know why. They're so involved in what they're doing, I hardly think they'd notice. She's not really listening. She reaches into her handbag and comes out with a manila envelope. She hands it to him. He tucks it into his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You included a recent picture, and addresses?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yes. (a beat) ..-And this is strictly confidential?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ‘Course it is. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, I oughta shove off. I have a lot of getting around to do, and I don't want to rush. She looks at him coolly and gets out of the car, leaving the door open. He stares at it for a moment, then leans over and pulls it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seedy two-part commercial block. A late model Dodge coupe pulls over to the curb. John gets out. He shrugs his jacket on as he heads into a small office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheaply furnished reception room. John comes in. His secretary, SUSAN, is sitting behind the desk. She's a lanky, sunburned girl, barely past twenty.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (brusque, but not unpleasant) Any messages? She pushes a phone message slip toward him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The judge postponed your alimony hearing another twenty- one days. He picks up the message slip.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: ...I called to order those office supplies? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh --

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) -- and they said that your account was past due. They wouldn't accept any new charges.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) All right. I'll pick them up myself. He heads into his private office. She gathers her things.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Should I bother coming in tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Half day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped office with a busy, cluttered look. Bookshelves lined with legal codes, a couple of file cabinets, stacks of legal pads, a Dictaphone recorder. John sits at his desk, which is covered with work he hasn't gotten to. He's on the phone. The sun cuts through the blinds behind him in glaring strips.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Believe me, I'm aware of that, but this is my divorce here... (listens) I handled it myself, so I know the alimony's subject to review. (listens) Because I'm the one who put in the provision that says the court has to re-examine it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12 He swivels his chair toward the window, squints, closes the blind slats.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) That's fine, but they still have to rule on whether the payments should be discontinued. (listens) I don't think you understand. I've reached the point where I'm sending her everything I make, and I can't do it anymore. (listens) Well, if she's working, she doesn't need it -- she's self- sufficient. (listens) Okay, I don't have time for this. I have too much to do. You know where to reach me. (listens) Yeah, ‘bye. He slams the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parking lot that overlooks the water. Beaumont's car is parked at the water's edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tucking into a hamburger. He has some fries spread out on a paper napkin on the dashboard, a cup filled with soda in the cup-holder. There's a heap of napkins on the passenger seat. He looks out the window. John's car pulls up, stops. John gets out and approaches. Beaumont rolls his window down. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Get in. John glances into the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ...Why don't we talk out here.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: I'm eating. (a beat) You want some fries?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: All right. I'm almost finished.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Finish out here. Beaumont gets out of the car, the burger in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: You're in a good mood. (a beat) What's the matter -- you fall short on your alimony again?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: I'm a private investigator. It's my job to know these things.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Right. (a beat) -..You meet with Mrs. Conovan?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What'd you think? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: She's an eyeful. (a beat) You two an item?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna dignify that with an answer.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (smiling) You could dignify it with a no.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (all business) .--How long's it gonna take?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Depends on how long it takes her husband to make a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be too long.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (a slight smile) I'm a divorce attorney. It's my job to know these things. Beaumont bolts down the last of his burger, then wipes the grease off his hands with a napkin. He bunches the napkin up and tosses it onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (suddenly serious) What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Pick that up.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Are you serious? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: There's a fifty dollar fine for littering, and I'm an officer of the court. (a beat) Pick it up. Beaumont looks at John, realizes he's serious. With a sigh, he bends down, picks up the napkin, stuffs it into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (slightly amused) You always like this? John turns, heads to his car.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I don't like it when people don't clean up after themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modest Spanish-style houses. John's car swings into the driveway of a stucco house with a tile roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John comes in, throws his jacket across a chair, sets his briefcase down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John opens the refrigerator and stands there for a moment, trying to cool off. He pulls a beer off the rack. INT. JOHN'S LIVING ROOM - LATE AFTERNOON 10Cc John walks over to the window, looks out, loosens his tie, sips his beer. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John looks at his reflection in the mirror. He turns the faucet on, gets a handful of water, splashes it on his face. The water runs down his chin and drips. He looks at himself again. A smile pulls at the corners of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street lined with mirrored, shimmering buildings. Expensive condominiums and soaring commercial structures. Beaumont sits in his car, eyes fixed on the entrance of a tall office building across the street. He wears a desultory shave. His clothes are limp, unfresh. There's a half-eaten sandwich in a wrapper on the dashboard. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16 TOM CONOVAN strides out of the building. He's a powerfully built man in his fifties, nicely dressed in a well-cut suit. He's carrying an expensive attache case. He looks up and down the crowded street, then starts walking. After a moment, he blends in with dozens of other people. Men in tailored suits and women in stylish dresses. Beaumont jots a few notes on a small pad. Sweat glistens on his round cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A golden-hued mansion fanned by towering palm trees. Gloria's Mercedes is parked in the driveway. Tom's Cadillac convertible pulls in next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide sweep of emerald grass. Sunlight glitters off a spectacular pool. Gloria is in the water, swimming laps. She swims with a perfect crawl and a powerful kick. Tom comes out, walks down to the end of the pool. There's a glass-topped table with an umbrella and several deck chairs. He eases himself gingerly into one of the chairs and watches Gloria. She does a barrel turn, swims another length, and then climbs out of the pool. She's wearing a skintight racing style swimsuit, one piece, cut high on the legs. Water glistens off her lean, athletic body. She grabs a towel, pats herself dry.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You're home early.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Got a meeting tonight, wanna change clothes. (conversationally) That a new suit? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: No. She gathers her wet hair in both hands, sweeps it up off the nape of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got time for a swim?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, I should go. He rubs his eyes. He's tired.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: -.-What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ah, it's this new high-rise. We're scheduled to break ground in about a month, but the construction loan hasn't closed yet.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Can't you just postpone the ground-breaking?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (smiling thinly) Right. I guess I'm too dumb to understand. As they're talking, a Cuban maid comes out of the house carrying a tray with a glass of iced tea on it. She's in her early twenties. Even in her sexless uniform she's a striking woman. Her name is AURORA RUIZ.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tom) You think you'll be back in time for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (distracted) No. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18 Aurora sets the tray down, turns, and heads back into the house. She moves with an easy sure-footed grace. As she walks away, Tom watches her. His nostrils flare. His eyes glaze. Gloria notes this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She new?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What happened to Maria? Gloria picks up her drink, takes a sip, holds the cool glass against her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: She wasn't really doing her job. I had to let her go.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about this one -- the pay the same?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (exhaling irritably) Of course. I know what the budget is. She turns and walks toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora is in the kitchen, standing at the counter, cleaning up from dinner. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, having just come home, walks past the kitchen. He's in a suit, his attache case in one hand. He stops and watches her. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16 19 She leans over the sink, rinses a plate, loads it into the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You like it here? She turns around, a little startled. After an awkward pause, she gives him a small, polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (with an accent) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mrs. Conovan -- you getting along with her?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (a little uncomfortable) Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (smiling) Good. (a beat) You have a problem, you can always come to me, okay?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Thank you. He stands there for a moment, smiling, and then he turns away. She watches him as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lush flower garden. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20 Aurora is cutting flowers, placing them into a basket. Gloria is standing nearby. She's wearing a large sun hat.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: ..-Have you decided?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Ay, sefora. (a beat) This is hard for me.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Think about your family. You'll have enough money to bring them here from Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (close to tears) I know. But for me to do this... She trails off, snips a flower off with her clippers.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Look, you've seen how he treats me. If you help me, I'll be able to get a divorce, and this house will be mine. You'll have a place here with me as long as you want. Aurora is on the verge of great emotion now. Gloria takes hold of her arms.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (firmly) Look at me. Aurora slowly looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calmly) I know how hard this is. (a beat) You believe in God, don't you? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17 18 21

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (softly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Then you know that if you ask Him to forgive you, He will. Aurora nods.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA
dialogues.text: (regaining her composure) ...-What if Mr. Conovan doesn't want me?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (laughing sharply) Have you seen the way he looks at you? Aurora flushes with shyness. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, then, just remember -- the best way to chase something is to let it chase you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John comes in. He crosses the reception room, opens the door to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is sitting in a chair in front of John's desk. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: How'd you get in?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Your secretary let me in, before she left. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  22

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have come here. We need to be careful. She gets up and moves toward him. She puts her hands around his neck and pulls his head toward hers, until their mouths all but touch.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I'm always careful. Besides, you're my attorney. We could account for a couple of visits, couldn't we?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Don't be angry... She kisses him. He pulls back, gazes at her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that look?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're with me. (a beat) You could have any man you want.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You are the man I want.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: All my life, men have been choosing me. Now I'm choosing you. Her arms tighten around him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to go ahead with this thing? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yes... (pulling back, looking into his eyes) Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ..-It's just that I've seen a lot of people get divorced. I've been through it. And it's never easy.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: It's the only way to get everything we want.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: My husband thinks I should be able to manage with what he gives me, which is a generous amount for a reasonable woman. (smiling) It just so happens that I'm not a reasonable woman. (a beat) Besides, we're doing this for us. I thought that's what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Don't say it if you don't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I mean it. I wouldn't want to be with anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Neither would I.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Even if we weren't doing this? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ..-But I know I could never give you what he could.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I had the locks changed this morning.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't live here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let me in. There is no response.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on... (a beat) We can discuss this.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You can discuss it with my attorney. He pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Open the goddamn door! He pounds on the door again, then steps back and stares at it. He blinks with vacant eyes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John is cruising along. His cellular phone rings. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. (listens) Uh-huh. (listens) All right. I'll be there soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John rings the bell. The door opens, and Gloria is there. She is smiling. She steps away from the door, and John enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria leads John through the house toward the pool.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (looking around) Aurora here?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I sent her out to run some errands.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where's your husband?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: When he came home this afternoon I told him I'd had the locks changed. He's already gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Gloria come out of the house. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  46 49 She stretches herself out on a chaise lounge. He shucks off his suit jacket, sits in a deck chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Any idea where he might spend the night? She turns her face toward the sun.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I think we should serve him with the papers as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He'll probably sleep on his boat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don't think he'd check into a hotel?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: That's the interesting thing about Tom -- he's got more money than he knows what to do with, but he'd rather die than spend any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is unloading gear and supplies from the trunk of his car. A sleek ocean-going yacht is tied up at the dock behind him. A car wheels into the parking lot. A man gets out. He walks up to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Tom Conovan? Tom looks up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  47 50

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. The man flourishes a sheaf of typewritten pages.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: These are for you. The man unceremoniously hands over the documents, then walks away. Tom looks at the papers. The top page reads: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE 11TH CIRCUIT IN AND FOR DADE COUNTY, FLORIDA. FAMILY DIVISION. IN RE: THE DISSOLUTION OF MARRIAGE. "Petitioner: Wife." Tom's jaw sags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-appointed conference room. John and Gloria are seated at a long table. John's nerves are clearly on edge. Gloria, looking cool in a fitted skirt suit, is preternaturally calm. Across the table, Tom is seated next to his attorney, SAM MASTERSON. He's a heavy man in his late fifties, sharply dressed in a custom suit. Tom flips through the photos of him and Aurora. His face is grim. He passes the photos to Masterson. Masterson glances at a couple of them, lays them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: At this point my client is willing to consider reconciliation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We've ruled that out. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  51

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: Then I'd like to propose a thirty day cooling off period before initiating any proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: My client has made a decision. She doesn't need any more time.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: (nodding equably) All right. If you've got a proposal, let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Monthly alimony payments in the amount of twenty thousand dollars, plus sole possession of the house and fifty percent of all cash and liquid assets.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: (smiling tightly) Let's be reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That is reasonable. Your client signed a prenuptial agreement. I believe you drew it up for him, so I'm sure you're familiar with its provisions. And I'm sure you realize that a court is going to rule in our favor.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not as sure you are.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Your client plainly violated the agreement's fidelity clause. Gloria gives Tom a hurt, reproachful look. It seems perfectly sincere. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: I think that's for a court to decide. John looks squarely at Masterson.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Look, I have a witness who can testify that your client checked into a motel with another woman, I have a copy of his statement for the room, and I have photos of everything. The color has drained from Masterson's face. He compresses his lips into a narrow seam.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now: you can allow your client to be humiliated in a very public way, or we can avoid all of that and agree on a settlement. It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Gloria, for God's sake. Can't we talk about this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: My client is not here to answer questions. You have her terms.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: Her terms are outrageous.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ..-All right, then. If there's nothing else, I think we're finished. He points to the photos.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can keep those, and the receipt from the motel. We have copies. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  53

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Gloria) Shall we? John and Gloria stand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tom and his attorney) Gentlemen. He opens the door, holds it for Gloria, follows her out. Tom sits there and watches them go. He is white with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Gloria step into an elevator. John presses a button. The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Gloria are alone in the elevator. They look at each other for a moment. She moves closer to him, then kisses him deeply and pins him against the wall. She reaches bluntly between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Is this for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Gloria step outside, keeping a respectable distance from each other, casually smoothing their clothes. They head across the parking lot toward their cars. He is smiling. Her face is flushed with excitement. Her eyes are brilliant. They walk in silence for a moment. When they do speak, they don't look at each other. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I want you more right now than I ever have.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (grinning) Really. They come to her car. He turns, offers his handshake. She takes his hand, shakes it for show.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Will you follow me back to the house? He nods. She gets into the car. He looks around, then heads toward his own car.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 51
dialogues.text: Beaumont stands behind a pillar. He's been watching John and Gloria. He takes a small pad out of his hip pocket, makes a note. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John follows Gloria into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: We did it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's not completely done.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He can't contest anything. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  55

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It still has to be presented to the court for written approval. The judge has to sign off on it.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I thought you were excited. A smile doesn't entirely hide his wariness.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Then don't worry so much. She heads to the bar. She picks up a tumbler, fills it with ice, splashes some bourbon into it, hands it to him. She fixes one for herself, holds it up to the light. She taps her glass against his.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To us. They drink. She cracks an ice cube between her teeth. She sits on the sofa, sinks back onto it, crosses her legs. Her drink dangles from her hand. She swings her upper leg gently.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with a sexy pout) So...what we should we do now?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (smiling) I don't know. He moves toward her. He sets his glass down and lightly strokes her cheek. She sets her glass down, holding his gaze. He bends down and kisses her. She pulls him to her tightly, moving her hands over his body. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John stirs and wakes up. He's alone in the bed. He scrubs at his eyes with his knuckles, looks around. The bathroom door is open and the shower is running. He swings his feet to the floor, sits on the edge of the bed, hunches forward. He notices a framed photo on the nightstand. The photo shows Tom and Gloria standing on a sunstruck beach. Tom's wearing a long beach robe, and Gloria is in a swimsuit. John traces his finger down Gloria's leg. Then his eyes shift over to Tom, whose head is thrown back slightly. Tom is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to do something about that. John turns his head. Gloria, fresh out of the shower, is framed in the doorway of the bathroom. She has a plush bath sheet wrapped tightly around her shapely figure. She moves past him, plucks the photo off the nightstand, tosses it into a drawer. She sits down next to him on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-We don't have to hide from anyone now. He rubs the back of his neck. She moves behind him on the bed, starts lightly massaging his neck and shoulders. She speaks softly into his ear:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can finally be together. Take care of each other. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And with the money we've got, you won't have any problem making those alimony payments.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (laughing) My ex-wife'll be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I'm sure she will be. But none of that matters, does it? No one else really matters now. It's just us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: When are you going to pay Aurora?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: When the divorce is finalized. (a beat) And then I'm going to fire her.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: You saw the pictures. You've seen her body. You don't think I want that body walking around in front of you every day, do you? He lies down on the bed. She lies down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It's good to know that you trust me so much.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Sorry... (a beat) It's been a long time since I was in a loving relationship. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54 58

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You've been married for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (laughing mournfully) That's what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You don't consider that a relationship?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. It never really felt like he was my husband. (a beat) It felt more like...an arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: An "arrangement"?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was like we had a deal. He actually used those words. "Let's make a deal."

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ...What was the deal?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: My looks. His money.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: ..-That's romantic.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well, I knew what I had to offer him, and he knew what he had to offer me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of seagulls wheel around lazily over the water. Tom's car pulls up. He gets out. He's wearing a T-shirt, a pair of shorts, deck shoes. He has a few days of beard on his face. He walks out onto the dock, pauses to admire his boat. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  59

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's a beauty. Tom starts, turns, looks around. Beaumont is standing in the parking lot. He pushes his hat back on his head, gestures toward the boat.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You take her out much?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (smiling inscrutably) I'm the man's gonna haul your ass out of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Beaumont sit at the stern, each with a beer.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (dry, matter-of-fact) I've done a lot of work for John, but when he called me about your wife, I knew there was something strange about it. The way he talked about her. It got my attention. I decided to do some freelance work, started tailing him. Saw him meet up with your wife in a parking lot. Followed them to a motel, got some nice pictures of them together. (a beat) All of this went down before I took the pictures of you. Tom sits there, waiting for more. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How much? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You get right to it, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (sipping his drink) Well, I'd say that depends on how much you want what I have.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What -- some pictures?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, no. These are not “some pictures." These are the pictures that are going to nullify the infidelity charge your wife is using to take away a whole lot of your money. From what I've heard, she's doing quite a number on you. Quite a set-up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (watchful) What do you mean, "set-up"?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: The girl -- Aurora? I went to the agency she works out of. Your wife had a cattle call at your house before she picked her. Seems she was looking for a very specific type of girl. (smiling) The type you'd find irresistible.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (staggered) .+-The girl was in on it?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: You were there. You tell me. Did she come on to you, ever? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  61

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) ..-No.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: And that night?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She was waiting for a bus. We wound up going to a bar... (a beat) How'd you know where we were?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: It's my job to know these things.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (thinking out loud) I wonder how much Gloria's paying her.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Not enough, considering.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to give a deposition?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (getting up to leave) Absolutely. No extra charge.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: All right. I'll call my lawyer, see if I can get an extension on the hearing. (draining his glass) You bring me the pictures, we'll talk about money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom's car is parked next to Beaumont's. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont sits quietly in the driver's seat as Tom pores over a series of 8 x 10 black-and-white photos. The photos, taken through a telephoto lens, show John and Gloria in bed. Tom slowly flips through the photos. He turns and gazes out the window.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (bemused) You know, a month after we met, she said we should get married. I said, Don't you want to get to know me a little more? She said, Why, does it get better? (laughing bitterly) My family never liked her. We had a small wedding. Flew down to Santo Domingo, hired a local band, got married on the beach. She said she didn't want a thing in the world except to be with me... Beaumont pats his pockets, takes out a roll of antacid tablets. He pops a couple into his mouth and chews them. He grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: I'll tell you the way I look at it, the ones who say they don't want anything always get more in the end. Tom carefully slides the photos into a manila envelope. Beaumont rubs his nose with the back of his hand. Tom hands Beaumont a fat pay envelope. Beaumont opens the envelope with his thick fingers, counts the money inside. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  63

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--I've been thinking... (a beat) I'm not sure how much good those pictures are gonna do you.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ...They prove she was having an affair with her lawyer. But they don't prove she set you up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What're you suggesting?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: I'm suggesting you'd be on firmer ground if you had another piece of evidence.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Like, say, a taped confession.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (laughing) And how do you propose I get that?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: There're ways.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Really.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Such as...? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  64

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: The less you know about it the better. Tom considers this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: When could I have it by?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Few days. Sooner, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ...All right... He gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont heads down the hall to John's office carrying a tool kit. He moves quietly, looking relaxed. He kneels in front of the door. He opens the tool kit and starts using lock-picking tools on the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaumont enters, closes the door, locks it. He takes out a penlight and turns it on. He flashes it around the office, finds the phone. He goes over to the phone, picks it up, unscrews the earpiece. He takes a small, round listening device out of his pocket. He peels off the backing to expose the adhesive. He attaches the listening device inside the phone, puts the phone back together. He heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind John's office. Beaumont's car is parked nearby. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  65 Beaumont is dialing a number. He waits, clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone starts ringing in the reception room. Susan picks it up, then hits the hold button.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (yells) ) John. It's for you. He wouldn't give his name. (a beat) You want him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sure. John swivels in his chair so that he can see Susan in the reception room. As she hangs up her phone, she gives him a strange, ambivalent look. He watches her as she goes back to work. INTERCUT BETWEEN BEAUMONT AND JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hiya John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Listen, I wanted to ask you a question.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62 66

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ...When you and your girlfriend decided to set up her husband, whose idea was it to bring in the maid?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What? Beaumont hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver's side door opens and Beaumont gets in. He puts on a pair of headphones. The headphones are connected to a radio surveillance receiver. The receiver is hooked up to a tape recorder. We hear the phone ringing in the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through headphones ) ..-Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through headphones ) It's me...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I just got a call. I think Beaumont knows something.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: About what...?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You, me, Aurora. He knows about the whole thing...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't see how he could.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, he does.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (chafing) Well, what do you expect me to do?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -+-I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look, you're a lawyer. He can't do anything unless he has some evidence, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right...

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, then, don't worry about it. (a beat) .--I can't really talk now. I'll call you later, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (still distraught) Okay. We hear a click on the line. Beaumont takes off the headphones, sits back, smiles. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty parking lot. Tom's car turns in. As the car's headlights sweep across the lot, they briefly throw light on Beaumont's car, which idles unobtrusively in the darkness. Tom parks, gets out. Beaumont rolls his window down.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ‘Evening, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom settles himself into the passenger seat. He glances at Beaumont, who's rumpled and sweating.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: You know, a lot of people come here at night. You'd be surprised. Beaumont takes out a handkerchief and wipes the sweat from the palms of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (getting expansive) Sometimes I'll see two cars pull in and park next to each other. The drivers'1ll go off somewhere in one of the cars. I jot down the license plate numbers and look ‘em up the next day. If their listings don't match, there's a chance they're married to other people. And if they are, I'll place a call to the spouses. I've found a few clients that way. He mops his brow. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-The things people think they can get away with.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You ever been married?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: No. Can't say I have. Tom turns and peers out the window.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It does strange things to people.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: Well, despite my line of work, I've seen a few happily married couples. Tom shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Marriage has got nothing to do with happiness. Beaumont laughs at this. His amusement is genuine and unalloyed.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: I'd say you've got a particular slant on the subject. Tom is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (unsmiling) Yeah, I do. (a beat) You have something for me? Beaumont dips into his jacket pocket with two fingers, pulls out a tape. He hands it Tom.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: ..-And I believe you have something for me... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  70 Tom slips the tape into his pocket, then hands Beaumont a thick pay envelope. Beaumont tucks the envelope into his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You're not gonna count it?

dialogues.speaker: BEAUMONT
dialogues.text: (smiling) Nah, I trust ya. Tom pulls a roll of bills out of his pocket. He peels off a twenty, hands it to Beaumont.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Here. Get your car washed. He gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, richly decorated office. Tom sits across from Masterson. He has just slapped the tape on the desktop, next to the photos of John and Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: And he's willing to testify that he took these before he took the ones of you and the girl?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: You ever hear the term, "connivance?" Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (steepling his fingers) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, essentially, it's when someone sets up a situation so tempting that someone else will commit a wrongdoing in the pursuit of that temptation. I've seen the pictures. This girl definitely falls into that category.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Which means...? Masterson leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
dialogues.text: Which means your wife is in for a very rude awakening.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What about the tape. Is it admissable in court?

dialogues.speaker: MASTERSON
